title: â€˜100 Liters of Goldâ€™ Review: A Darkly Comic Ode to Finlandâ€™s Ancient Homebrew
description: With an endearing black comedy set in the provinces, which adopts the visual style of a â€™60s Western, prolific writer-director Teemu Nikki salutes h
body:
With an endearing black comedy set in the provinces, which adopts the visual style of a â€™60s Western, prolific writer-director Teemu Nikki salutes his countryâ€™s (and his familyâ€™s) tradition of sahti-making. â€œ100 Liters of Goldâ€ follows two dysfunctional middle-aged sisters, third-generation makers of the strong farmhouse ale. In their village of SysmÃ¤, sahti is a must to mark births, weddings and funerals, as well as almost everything in between. Touching on issues such as alcoholism and family trauma, but with a light touch, Finlandâ€™s international Oscar submission provides a breath of fresh air (albeit one redolent with alcohol) amongst the serious dramas in this category.
	

	Pirkko (Elina KnihtilÃ¤) and Taina (Pirjo Lonka) live in a ramshackle house on what was once the family farm, but their main source of income comes from their tasty home brew â€” or it would, if they didnâ€™t consume so much of it themselves. Then, thereâ€™s the friends and neighbors, even the local pastor (Vilma Melasniemi ), who continue to make off with full containers on credit.


	When their younger sister PÃ¤ivi (Ria Kataja) commissions 100 liters of the golden liquid for her upcoming wedding, Pirkko and Taina promise to concoct a batch worthy of a perfect 10. But 22 days later, when it is ready, they once again get too tempted by their own brewhouse magic and by the time the wedding day nears, thereâ€™s no more sahti left.

	With their reputation as top brewmakers to protect, as well as a feeling of guilt toward PÃ¤ivi, who lost her lower leg after a car accident when they were all driving drunk, the gals set off with Pirkkoâ€™s would-be suitor, the chain-smoking milquetoast Hauki-Hikkanen (Ville Tiihonen) at the wheel. They are determined to get some decent sahti by hook or by crook.
	

	Nikki spends a tad too much time on the escapades of their single-minded quest. He also includes multiple showdowns with their nasty, leering cousin Ponu-Paavo (Jari Pehkonen), who covets their business and the special wooden brewing trough (the kuurina) left to them by their grandfather.

	The kuurina and other tools and tricks of the sahti trade are lovingly incorporated into the storyline, as Pirkko explains the brewing process to PÃ¤iviâ€™s fiancÃ© (Jakob Ohrman). Although thereâ€™s plenty of boozing in the film, the dangers of over-indulging are made very clear. Thereâ€™s PÃ¤iviâ€™s injury, which continues to haunt Taina; the client who dies before he can pay off his debt; Pirkkoâ€™s hospitalization for alcohol poisoning; and the womenâ€™s father (Pertti Sveholm), who now depends on Antabuse, but still likes his daughters to leave him samples of their latest batch.

	No matter how cartoonish the action, the fine ensemble of actors plays it seriously, and you can see the intelligence shine from their eyes. Nikki maintains that he likes to cast before he writes, and with KnihtilÃ¤ and Lonka, who work in theater as well as film and television, he has a starring pair who give it their all.

	Nikki and cinematographer Jarmo Kiuru, another SysmÃ¤ native, shoot in a 1:2.39 widescreen ratio with a dusty, warm color palette. When Pirkko and Taina face off with Ponu, they could be rival outlaws staring each other down and refusing to give up ground.

	The colorful costumes by Anna Vilppunen (â€œTom of Finland,â€ â€œSisuâ€) also continue the Western motif, while composer Marco Biscarini was a student of Ennio Morricone. All things considered, Nikki proves himself a native son of which SysmÃ¤ can be proud â€” much like Olavi Virta, the â€œking of Finnish tango,â€ whose music the film also celebrates.

	So far, only Nikkiâ€™s previous Finnish Oscar entry, â€œEuthanizerâ€ (2017) has been distributed Stateside. But with the pace and range of his work, as well as an upcoming English-language project, it shouldnâ€™t be too long before American audiences get a chance to catch up.

schema.headline: â€˜100 Liters of Goldâ€™ Review: A Darkly Comic Ode to Finlandâ€™s Ancient Homebrew

title: Elliot Graingeâ€™s 10K Projects Sued by Internet Money Label Over Breach of Contract and Misconduct
description: Elliot Graingeâ€™s 10K Projects has been sued by Taz Taylorâ€™s Internet Money, which claims that the company breached fiduciary and contractual obligat
body:
Elliot Graingeâ€™s 10K Projects has been sued by Taz Taylorâ€™s Internet Money, which claims that the company breached fiduciary and contractual obligations by withholding millions of dollars.

	The suit, filed in Los Angeles Federal Court on Tuesday and reviewed by Variety, outlines a pattern of contract violations and misconduct regarding profit sharing, among other claims. It alleges that 10K knowingly cross-collateralized accounts and evaded paying Internet Moneyâ€™s earned share of profits as part of its joint venture.
	

	Internet Money initially entered into the JV with 10K in Aug. 2019 to sign and develop artists with a 50/50 split of net profits. Following the contract execution, Taylor began releasing music outside of the scope of the deal that grew in popularity, leading to a 2020 negotiation for an amendment that extended the JV through June 2024.


	According to the suit, first reported by Billboard, 10K engaged in a â€œconsistent and repeated pattern of violations and breaches of its obligations under the Agreement in numerous ways.â€ Per the agreement, 10K was required to get approval from Internet Money regarding all creative and business decisions, as well as any reallocations of A&R costs and marketing. Internet Money claims that 10K did not comply with the agreement, and â€œunilaterally incurred and charged tens of millions of dollars in deductionsâ€ without approval.

	More specifically, Internet Money accuses 10K of â€œdilutingâ€ and â€œeffectively giving awayâ€ profits from the 2020 hit â€œLemonade,â€ a global smash that peaked at No. 6 on the Billboard Hot 100. The suit claims that 10K gave a $500,000 advance to an unnamed artist, then renegotiated the agreement without Internet Moneyâ€™s approval. It also alleges that 10K failed to execute a profit participation agreement with Taylor in respect to Iann Dior, and has impeded requests for an audit.
	

	Grainge, who became CEO of Atlantic Music Group in Oct. 2024, has spent years building his 10K business, which is now housed under Warner and counts Trippie Redd and Ice Spice as signees. A representative for 10K responded to Variety with no comment.

	Internet Money is seeking millions in damages on causes including breach of contract, accounting, fraudulent inducement, unjust enrichment and more.

schema.headline: Elliot Graingeâ€™s 10K Projects Sued by Internet Money Label Over Breach of Contract and Misconduct

title: Raven-SymonÃ© Separates Bill Cosbyâ€™s â€˜Horrificâ€™ Sexual Assault Allegations From His Cultural Impact: His Show â€˜Changed Americaâ€™
description: During a recent appearance on the â€œHate to Break It to Yaâ€ podcast, Raven-SymonÃ© says she separates Bill Cosbyâ€˜s impact on the TV industry from his
body:
During a recent appearance on the â€œHate to Break It to Yaâ€ podcast, Raven-SymonÃ© says she separates Bill Cosbyâ€˜s impact on the TV industry from his â€œhorrificâ€ sexual assault allegations.

	â€œSeparate the creator from the creation,â€ she said. â€œAnd thatâ€™s just where I live. The creation changed America. Changed television.â€

	â€œHeâ€™s also been accused of some horrific things,â€ SymonÃ© added. â€œThat does not excuse, but thatâ€™s his personal [life]. So personally, keep that there, and then business-wise, know what he did there as well. Like you said, both can live, and I think our culture is right toâ€¦donâ€™t do wrong. Donâ€™t do wrong personally. You just canâ€™t do wrong.â€
	

	SymonÃ© appeared as Olivia Kendall alongside Cosby on â€œThe Cosby Showâ€ from 1989 until the showâ€™s end in 1992. Cosby co-created the show in 1984 and starred as Dr. Heathcliff Huxtable. â€œThe Cosby Showâ€ earned six Emmy awards and ran for 197 episodes.

	Cosby first faced sexual assault allegations back in 2004 from Andrea Constand, but it wasnâ€™t until 2014 that the accusations became widely known. In 2014, Barbara Bowman, who testified in support of Constandâ€™s civil suit against Cosby, penned an op-ed for The Washington Post titled, â€œBill Cosby raped me. Why did it take 30 years for people to believe my story?â€

	In the years following, dozens more women came forward with their own allegations against Cosby. In 2016, he was ordered to stand trial by the Montgomery County Magisterial District Court for sexual assault. The trial began in June 2017 and ended in a mistrial after twelve days.

	Cosby was eventually convicted in a 2018 retrial on three felony counts of aggravated indecent assault and sentenced to three to 10 years in prison. The Supreme Court of Pennsylvania overturned the conviction in 2021 due to a previous agreement Cosby had with Montgomery County prosecutor Bruce Castor. The pair agreed Cosby could not be prosecuted if he provided a deposition in Constandâ€™s civil case.

schema.headline: Raven-SymonÃ© Separates Bill Cosbyâ€™s â€˜Horrificâ€™ Sexual Assault Allegations From His Cultural Impact: His Show â€˜Changed Americaâ€™

title: â€˜Gossip Girlâ€™ Star Taylor Momsen Battled Studio Execs to Quit the Show and Got Called â€˜Ungratefulâ€™: â€˜Fâ€” You! How Dare You Judge This?â€™
description: Taylor Momsen was the latest guest on the â€œCall Her Daddyâ€ podcast and reminisced on the painstaking effort it took to quit The CWâ€™s â€œGossip Girlâ€ d
body:
Taylor Momsen was the latest guest on the â€œCall Her Daddyâ€ podcast and reminisced on the painstaking effort it took to quit The CWâ€™s â€œGossip Girlâ€ during Season 4. Momsen, a child actor who had already appeared in major films such as â€œHow the Grinch Stole Christmasâ€ and â€œSpy Kids 2â€ before signing on to â€œGossip Girl,â€ originated the role of Jenny Humphrey on the series. Jenny was one of the more divisive characters. Momsen wanted to quit the show in Season 4 to pursue her dreams of touring with her band, The Pretty Reckless. 
	

	â€œI kind of just Irish-dipped. I just wasnâ€™t on the script the next week,â€ Momsen said (via E! News). â€œThey all knew I was making music. They all knew I had a band. I would play them stuff because I was working on the first record while I was on the show. I would come in and play songsâ€¦ but I donâ€™t think anyone knew how serious I was at that stage.â€


	â€œIt was an easy decision for me,â€ she continued. â€œTo actually get [out of] a contract was not easyâ€¦ it was a very long battle of me arguing [with] everyone and going, â€˜Get me outta this. I canâ€™t do this anymore. This is killing me. I have something else I want to do with my life, and it has nothing to do with this, and I canâ€™t be stuck here anymore.'â€

	Despite her pleas, Momsen said studio executives at Warner Bros. Television deemed her â€œungratefulâ€ for trying to get off a popular television series, adding: â€œYouâ€™re called all the things that come along with, â€˜How dare you turn your back on something thatâ€™s been so successful for you.'â€

	â€œI just went, â€˜Fuck you. You donâ€™t know what youâ€™re talking about. Youâ€™re not in my shoes, so how dare you judge this?'â€ Momsen said. â€œI was very defensive, but it came down to they wouldnâ€™t let me out of the contract. The head of Warner Bros. said, â€˜Fuck Taylor Momsen. No fucking way.â€™â€
	

	Fortunately for Momsen, she had â€œGossip Girlâ€ showrunners Stephanie Savage and Josh Schwartz on her side. They agreed to write Jenny out of the show in Season 4, even though Momsen was still contracted for more time. This meant that Momsen could not act in other projects until her â€œGossip Girlâ€ contract was up, even if she was no longer being written into scripts. Luckily, Momsen had no intention of acting anyway as she pivoted full-time to her music career.

	â€œI really have to credit them for doing that for me because they did not have to, and they wrote me out of the show so I could go on tour and be in a band,â€ Momsen said, noting that she has no resentment towards â€œGossip Girlâ€ all these years later. She even reprised Jenny in the showâ€™s 2012 series finale.

	â€œAs a fan of television and a fan of the shows, I love when you have the full cast together again,â€ Momsen said. â€œYou want to full-circle that and round it out.â€

	Watch Momsenâ€™s full interview on the â€œCall Her Daddyâ€ podcast in the video below.

schema.headline: â€˜Gossip Girlâ€™ Star Taylor Momsen Battled Studio Execs to Quit the Show and Got Called â€˜Ungratefulâ€™: â€˜Fâ€” You! How Dare You Judge This?â€™

title: Meghan Markle Returning to Acting for Amazon Movie With Lily Collins and Brie Larson
description: Meghan Markle is returning to the screen with a small cameo role in the feature â€œClose Personal Friends,â€ Variety has confirmed. Lily Collins, Jack
body:
Meghan Markle is returning to the screen with a small cameo role in the feature â€œClose Personal Friends,â€ Variety has confirmed. Lily Collins, Jack Quaid, Brie Larson and Henry Golding are starring in the comedy that is currently shooting around Los Angeles.

	Also appearing in the comedy are â€œSNLâ€ alum Melissa VillaseÃ±or, as well as Natasia Demetriou, Anna Konkle, Patti Harrison, Jack Shalloo and Dustin Demri-Burns.


	The story reportedly revolves around a â€œregularâ€ couple that meets a celebrity couple while on a trip to Santa Barbara. When the two couples become friends, lines are crossed and things get awkward.
	

	Jason Orley is directing from a screenplay by Isaac Aptaker, from a story on which they collaborated. Aptaker and Elizabeth Berger are producing. Orley, Aptaker and Berger previously worked together on Amazon MGMâ€™s rom-com â€œI Want You Back.â€

	Markle starred in â€œSuitsâ€ for seven seasons and appeared in films like â€œHorrible Bossesâ€ and â€œRemember Meâ€ before marrying Prince Harry in 2018. She has not acted in over seven years, though her and Prince Harryâ€™s banner Archewell Productions re-upped its first-look deal at Netflix back in August. Through the partnership, Markle has executive produced doc series like â€œPoloâ€ and â€œLive to Lead,â€ plus Markleâ€™s own lifestyle series â€œWith Love, Meghan,â€ which bowed it second season over the summer.

	â€œItâ€™s a new chapter, right?â€ Markle, 36, told Page Six when she gave up her gig on the USA networkâ€™s â€œSuitsâ€ to focus being the Duchess of Sussex. â€œIâ€™ve ticked this box, and I feel very proud of the work Iâ€™ve done there, and now itâ€™s time to work with [Harry] as a team.â€
	

	In 2020, the couple announced they were stepping back from royal duties and would split their time between Santa Barbara and the U.K.

	Amazon MGM had no comment.

schema.headline: Meghan Markle Returning to Acting for Amazon Movie With Lily Collins and Brie Larson

title: Serial Killings, Childhood Trauma Collide in GrX Studioâ€™s â€˜The Ones I Killedâ€™ at Taiwan Creative Content Fest
description: GrX Studio, the production company behind crime thrillers â€œCopycat Killerâ€ and â€œThe Victimsâ€™ Game,â€ is showcasing its latest project at the Taiwan C
body:
GrX Studio, the production company behind crime thrillers â€œCopycat Killerâ€ and â€œThe Victimsâ€™ Game,â€ is showcasing its latest project at the Taiwan Creative Content Fest (TCCF). â€œThe Ones I Killed and The Ones Who Killed Meâ€ is a psychological crime drama with plans for a U.S.-Taiwan co-production.

	The series, adapted from Akira Higashiyamaâ€™s novel of the same name, follows a Taiwanese psychiatrist who becomes entangled in U.S. serial killings spanning three decades. Each body serves as a brutal message, forcing him to confront a past he desperately tried to forget.
	

	â€œThe inspiration comes from the novelâ€™s capture of the fragile beauty of childhood friendship and the painful contrast that comes with adulthood,â€ producer Lee Wen-yi and executive producer Tseng Han-hsien tell Variety. â€œThat became the starting point for our adaptation.â€


	The narrative centers on two childhood friends, Jason and Morris, who grew up in dysfunctional families and vowed to become each otherâ€™s family. â€œThey are twin flames â€” light and shadow, yin and yang â€” illuminating each otherâ€™s tragic lives,â€ the producers explain. â€œBut one incident tears them apart, and their fates are reversed.â€

	When the pair reunite as adults, they find themselves on opposite sides of morality: Jason works as a psychiatrist assisting police, while Morris has become a serial killer challenging societyâ€™s definition of sanity. â€œThe mystery of the crime is no longer about who the killer is, but how evil comes into being,â€ the producers note. â€œHave we, in order to survive, ever killed the kindness in anotherâ€™s soul? Perhaps the real culprit is society itself.â€
	

	The project represents GrX Studioâ€™s continued exploration of the crime-thriller genre. â€œFrom â€˜Copycat Killerâ€™ to â€˜The Victimsâ€™ Game,â€™ the GrX team has continued to explore and expand the possibilities of the crime-thriller genre,â€ the producers say. â€œWith â€˜The Ones I Killed and The Ones Who Killed Me,â€™ we aim to take that vision even further â€” deepening our psychological and moral inquiry while pushing creative boundaries.â€

	The series will begin with a murder in Los Angeles, unfolding through the perspective of a Taiwanese psychiatrist who has lived in the U.S. for years as he reflects on his childhood in Taiwan. Filming is planned for both the U.S. and Taiwan, with the team actively seeking international co-production partners at TCCF.

	The projectâ€™s timing is deliberate. â€œThe world has been changing rapidly in recent years,â€ the producers observe. â€œAcross many countries, anti-immigration sentiments are rising, and people have begun to engage in deeper discussions about identity and immigration policies.â€ They note that original author Akira Higashiyama, who was born in Taiwan and later moved to Japan, brings a unique perspective on how different cultures shape identity.

	â€œAt its creative core, the series explores the interdependent relationship between good and evil â€” like yin and yang â€” as a way to examine belonging and otherness,â€ the producers say. â€œThe title itself suggests a mirror-like connection, just as the relationship between an investigator and a suspect in a crime thriller often reflects two sides of the same coin.â€

	The script is currently 80% complete, with the writing team aiming to finalize it by yearâ€™s end. Pre-production is slated for Q3 2026, with filming scheduled to commence in Q1 2027.

	The creative team includes executive producer Hank Tseng, known for his global perspective and keen market insight in developing culturally rich, cross-border content. Producer Lee Wen-yi brings expertise in crafting narratives that explore human complexity and social structures. The writing team comprises John Cheng, who specializes in social realism and crime genres rooted in Taiwanese culture; Chen Cheng-yu, a senior screenwriter based in the U.S. with experience in American TV structure and writersâ€™ room dynamics; Peng Huai-de, whose versatile storytelling balances emotional depth with entertainment value; and Cheng Wen-ting, who holds a masterâ€™s degree from NTUAâ€™s Department of Radio and Television.
	

	GrX Studio encompasses film and television production, talent management, IP development, and business strategy, with a presence across the Asian market.

schema.headline: Serial Killings, Childhood Trauma Collide in GrX Studioâ€™s â€˜The Ones I Killedâ€™ at Taiwan Creative Content Fest

title: â€˜Iâ€™m Not Everything I Want to Beâ€™ Review: A Queer Czech Photographer Co-Authors Her Documentary
description: While occasionally languorous, the 2026 Czech Oscar entry â€œIâ€™m Not Everything I Want to Beâ€ is one of the rare documentaries about an artist that go
body:
While occasionally languorous, the 2026 Czech Oscar entry â€œIâ€™m Not Everything I Want to Beâ€ is one of the rare documentaries about an artist that goes above and beyond to embody its subjectâ€™s creative spirit, often to a fault. Whereas chronicles of its ilk tend to simply perceive their subjectsâ€™ work at a distance, KlÃ¡ra TasovskÃ¡â€™s feature, about queer Czech photographer LibuÅ¡e JarcovjÃ¡kovÃ¡, conscripts her as a co-author by having her read from her journals throughout the 1970s and â€˜80s. It also uses her photographs, not just as a source, but as a primary medium. The film is composed entirely of her decades-old snapshots, and credits her as cinematographer. Â 
	

	The resultant photoroman (Ã  la Chris Markerâ€™s â€œLa JetÃ©eâ€) mimics movement through successive shots, and through the placement of each image on screen, while employing subtle foleys to create a soundscape of time and place. As JarcovjÃ¡kovÃ¡ travels from the former Czechoslovakia to Japan and West Berlin, navigating rejection and the lives of various lovers, the murmurs of voices, quiet footsteps and hums of crowded rooms accompany her striking black-and-white photography. Some images even expand and unfold, their hidden halves fading-in to reveal new layers and dimensions to the places and people she captured decades prior.


	While the movieâ€™s English language title speaks to a constant state of confusion and contrition, its original name, â€œJeÅ¡tÄ› nejsem, kÃ½m chci bÃ½t,â€ translates to the intriguing â€œIâ€™m Not Yet Who I Want to Beâ€ â€” note the â€œyetâ€ â€” hinting at the film being a diary of not just self-image, but of personal and artistic process. JarcovjÃ¡kovÃ¡, who has been dubbed the Nan Goldin of Czechoslovakia, captures stark and intimate images, revealing people through overexposed skin just as much as hiding them in shadow. TasovskÃ¡â€™s documentary is similar in this regard; it lines up just enough photographs and recollections to grant us access and insight, but not so much that weâ€™re satiated all at once.
	

	JarcovjÃ¡kovÃ¡ makes for a fascinating subject, especially as someone capturing her own emotional dissatisfaction through the contours of her body and face. However, owing to the nature of her photographs â€” slivers of time cemented in place, and never intended for motion â€” thereâ€™s only so long â€œIâ€™m Not Everything I Want to Beâ€ can go without feeling outstretched. While each of the images, individually, features the suggestion of motion (in some cases, ethereal strokes of light exposed at length), JarcovjÃ¡kovÃ¡â€™s collection as a whole isnâ€™t a narrative in nature, at least not in the way we might think of narratives in cinema. 

	A gallery of JarcovjÃ¡kovÃ¡â€™s work might gesture towards her larger story, meant to be pondered over at a leisurely pace. But TasovskÃ¡â€™s film charges forward breathlessly at breakneck speed. This isnâ€™t a cardinal sin, but the approach presents a challenge for the movie to overcome, which it only manages to in moments of denouement. Its connective tissue, however, might lose the viewer along the way, as it coheres only into a distant political analysis of the world around its subject, seldom offering us enough time to get fully absorbed in the meaning of her imagery.

	State homophobia is a key concern in JarcovjÃ¡kovÃ¡â€™s work, and she finds comfort through observation, highlighting life in all its hues, albeit behind closed doors. TasovskÃ¡ mirrors this creative instinct in energetic ways, between using strobing effects to match the intoxicating chaos of Pragueâ€™s queer nightlife (accompanied by a modern, techno-infused tracks by DJ GÃ„P) and by introducing color in fleeting moments of liberation. Beyond a point, JarcovjÃ¡kovÃ¡ considers herself a perpetual outsider, more comfortable at the margins â€” whether as an outcast in her own country (and among its Romani populace), or as a guest in someone elseâ€™s.

	The movie builds admirably to these moments, where the euphoria of fragile belonging is front and center. However, in the interim, one might become impatient for TasovskÃ¡ to turn the next corner of JarcovjÃ¡kovÃ¡â€™s story, leaving little room to ruminate, as a good photography exhibition would. The handshake of different artistic forms that the film attempts is commendable in spirit, and it often yields remarkable results, even if the whole is seldom satisfying.

schema.headline: â€˜Iâ€™m Not Everything I Want to Beâ€™ Review: A Queer Czech Photographer Co-Authors Her Documentary

title: Kathy Hilton on â€˜Real Housewives of Beverly Hillsâ€™ Season 15: â€˜Itâ€™s Pretty Brutalâ€™
description:
Kathy Hilton insists sheâ€™s not involved in any of the drama coming up in Season 15 of â€œThe Real Housewives of Beverly Hills.â€

	Even so, she warns,
body:
Kathy Hilton insists sheâ€™s not involved in any of the drama coming up in Season 15 of â€œThe Real Housewives of Beverly Hills.â€

	Even so, she warns, â€œItâ€™s pretty brutal.â€

	â€œThereâ€™s no Kathy Hilton drama,â€ she continued. â€œIâ€™m not really dramatic. All that drama makes me really sad. Theyâ€™re all just very comfortable in saying whatever they want and thatâ€™s what makes it brutal.â€


	I caught up with the Hilton matriarch Tuesday night at her home in Bel-Air, where she and daughter Nicky were hosting their annual Pajama Party. Presented by QVC, the soiree is a gifting suite of sorts â€“ guests filled personalized Hulken Bags with various free health and beauty products, Oh My Mahjong sets and Slatkin + Co candles, while sipping MoÃ«t & Chandon champagne and enjoying â€œcaviar bumpsâ€ courtesy of The Caviar Co placed on their top of their hands by the model-worthy waitstaff. 
	

	The event also served as a holiday toy drive as well as a benefit for the Los Angeles Mission, Yogiâ€™s House and Camp Crocker Rescue.

	Guests were encouraged â€“ and most obliged â€“ to wear festive pajamas from Hiltonâ€™s Printfresh collection.

	Earlier Tuesday, the first trailer dropped for the new â€œRHOBHâ€ season, featuring returning Housewife Denise Richards and newbie cast members stylist Rachel Zoe and businesswoman Amanda France.

	Full-time Housewives Erika Jayne, Dorit Kemsley, Kyle Richards, Bozoma St. John and Sutton Stracke are also back. Hilton and Jennifer Tilly welcome a new â€œfriendâ€ in the show, Natalie Swanston Fuller.

	â€œI had a couple of phone calls today from some of the girls [after they saw the trailer], letâ€™s just put it that way,â€ Hilton said. â€œSome of them were like, â€˜I canâ€™t believe so-and-so did this.â€™â€
	

	Hilton said Zoe, who is also marking her return to Bravo after starring in her own reality show for the cabler, â€œcame in and fit right in. â€¦ I donâ€™t think she caused any drama.â€

	Nicky Hilton teased that she makes an appearance in the season finale: â€œThe event was very dramatic, but me not included,â€ she said, smiling.

	Kathy added, â€œIt was bru-tal!â€

	Spotted at the party were Frances and Zoe, Jennie Garth, Dylan Mulvaney, screenwriter Sam Lansky, Christine Chiu, Crystal Kung Minkoff, Faye Resnick, Heather Dubrow, Joely Fisher, Nancy Davis, Sutton Stracke, Tommy Hilfiger, Dee Ocleppo, producer Hilary Shor and Maria Bakalova.

schema.headline: Kathy Hilton on â€˜Real Housewives of Beverly Hillsâ€™ Season 15: â€˜Itâ€™s Pretty Brutalâ€™

title: Golden Horse Winner Henry Tsai Takes Aim With â€˜Spent Bulletsâ€™ at Taiwan Creative Content Fest
description: Henry Tsai, the Golden Horse Award-winning screenwriter of â€œWinds of September,â€ is set to direct â€œSpent Bullets,â€ an adaptation of Terao Tetsuyaâ€™s
body:
Henry Tsai, the Golden Horse Award-winning screenwriter of â€œWinds of September,â€ is set to direct â€œSpent Bullets,â€ an adaptation of Terao Tetsuyaâ€™s acclaimed literary work, with the project selected for presentation at the Taiwan Creative Content Fest (TCCF).

	The film follows Silicon Valley engineers Wu Yi-Hsiang and Hsiao-Hua as they journey to Las Vegas to mourn their genius classmate Jie-Heng. During the highway trip, they must confront the intimacy, shame, and desire they once shared â€” a premise that explores the intersection of success, love, and human connection.
	

	â€œI was captivated by the plight of being a genius, and the subtle and hard-to-define erotic relationships in the stories,â€ Tsai said. â€œI was inspired to tell a story on screen that explores the correlation between success and love.â€


	The director emphasized the filmâ€™s emotional core: â€œSomeone will love you for who you are, no matter if youâ€™re successful or wealthy. You deserve that love, and you know how to give it as well as to receive it.â€

	Produced by Jacqueline W. Liu through Taipei-based Each Other Films, which she co-founded with Tiffany Yu-Chia Chen, the project is eyeing a May 2026 start for principal photography in the U.S., with Taiwan shoots scheduled to follow in June. The team is actively seeking financing and co-producing partners at TCCF.

	Each Other Filmsâ€™ recent slate includes the family drama â€œLittle Big Womenâ€ (2020), comedy series â€œThe Accidental Influencerâ€ (2024), and romantic comedy â€œPenguin Girlâ€ (2024).

	Tsai has built a strong festival pedigree with his short films. â€œLove After Timeâ€ earned nominations at both the Golden Horse Awards and Sitges Film Festival, while â€œLive Stream from Yuki <3â€ was selected for Sundance, Sitges, and Munich Film Festival. His short â€œMy Grandmaâ€ also received a Golden Horse nomination.
	

	The source material comes from Terao Tetsuya, a Taiwanese former Google software engineer operating under a pseudonym who spent eight years at the tech giant before turning to writing. His works â€œSpent Bulletsâ€ and â€œOverfittingâ€ have won several literature awards. â€œSpent Bulletsâ€ has already been translated into English and Korean.

schema.headline: Golden Horse Winner Henry Tsai Takes Aim With â€˜Spent Bulletsâ€™ at Taiwan Creative Content Fest

title: Glen Powell Premieres â€˜Running Manâ€™ in London, Demi Moore Stuns in Balenciaga in New York and More Red Carpet Photos: November 2025
description:
Nov 5, 2025 4:30pm PT	
	

	
		Glen Powell Premieres â€˜Running Manâ€™ in London, Demi Moore Stuns in Balenciaga in New York and More Red
body:
Nov 5, 2025 4:30pm PT	
	

	
		Glen Powell Premieres â€˜Running Manâ€™ in London, Demi Moore Stuns in Balenciaga in New York and More Red Carpet Photos: November 2025
	
	
			


			
			
	

									Lia Toby
	

		
	
				Just as everyone was packing up their Halloween costumes, November began with one of Hollywoodâ€™s glitziest and star-studded events of the year, LACMAâ€™s Art+Film gala. Cynthia Erivo, Salma Hayek and the mother-daughter duo of Cindy Crawford and Kaia Gerber were just some of the bold-faced names who stunned on the carpet and helped the museum raise a record-breaking $6.5 million.
At the same time, in New York City, Robert Pattinson and Jennifer Lawrence premiered â€œDie My Love.â€ A couple of nights later, Harrison Ford was the surprise guest at the Los Angeles premiere of his fellow â€œStar Warsâ€ series stars Joel Edgerton and Felicity Jonesâ€™ new drama â€œTrain Dreams.â€
And Christmas came early in Bel-Air when Kathy Hilton hosted her annual Pajama Party, presented by QVC, with â€œReal Housewives of Beverly Hillsâ€ stars Denise Richards and newbie Rachel Zoe scooping up freebies from candle company Slatkin + Co and enjoying caviar from The Caviar Co.
Check out the best photos of November 2025 below and make sure to keep checking back all month long for more.



			
			
	Lee Pace, Colman Domingo, Emilia Jones, Edgar Wright and Glen Powell
	
					
				Image Credit: Lia Toby			
			
	Lee Pace, Colman Domingo, Emilia Jones, Edgar Wright and Glen Powell premiere their new Paramount Pictures film â€œThe Running Manâ€ at Odeon Luxe Leicester Square on Nov. 5 in London.

		
			
			
	
					
				Image Credit: Stephanie Augello			
			
	Demi Moore stuns in Balenciaga at the Glamour Women of the Year Awards 2025 at The Plaza Hotel on Nov. 4 in New York City.

		
			
			
	Denise Richards and Kathy Hilton
	
					
				Image Credit: Getty Images for QVC			
			
	Denise Richards joins her â€œReal Housewives of Beverly Hillsâ€ co-star Kathy Hilton at her annual Pajama Party, sponsored by QVC, on Nov. 4 in Los Angeles.

		
			
			
	Tommy Hilfiger, Dee Ocleppo Hilfiger and Rachel Zoe
	
					
				Image Credit: Getty Images for QVC			
			
	Tommy Hilfiger, Dee Ocleppo Hilfiger and Rachel Zoe attend Kathy Hiltonâ€™s Pajama Party, presented by QVC, in Los Angeles.

		
			
			
	Lesley Silverman, Cheryl Paglierani, Chloe Popescu, Fara Leff and Theresa Peters
	
					
				Image Credit: Courtesy			
			
	UTAâ€™s Lesley Silverman (UTA), Cheryl Paglieran of CAA, Oscar de la Renta CMO Chloe Popescu, Klutch Sports Group COO Fara Leff and UTAâ€™s Theresa Peters the Oscar de la Renta Women in Entertainment Los Angeles Dinner at Cipriani Beverly Hills on Nov. 4.

		
			
			
	Joel Edgerton, Felicity Jones and Harrison Ford
	
					
				Image Credit: Michael Buckner			
			
	Joel Edgerton and Felicity Jones are joined by surprise guest Harrison Ford at Netflixâ€™s â€œTrain Dreamsâ€ Los Angeles premiere at the Egyptian Theater on Nov. 3.

		
			
			
	Michael Strahan, Robin Roberts and George Stephanopoulos
	
					
				Image Credit: ABC News			
			
	â€œGood Morning Americaâ€ hosts Michael Strahan, Robin Roberts and George Stephanopoulos celebrate the morning showâ€™s 50th anniversary at 7 Hudson Square in The Great Room in New York City.

		
			
			
	Brittany S. Hall, Tyler Perry and Shannon Thornton
	
					
				Image Credit: Paras Griffin/Getty Images for Amazon			
			
	Brittany S. Hall, Tyler Perry and Shannon Thornton attend â€œTyler Perryâ€™s Finding Joyâ€ screening at Regal Atlantic Station on Nov. 2 in Atlanta.

		
			
			
	LaKeith Stanfield, Robert Pattinson, Lynne Ramsay, Jennifer Lawrence and Sissy Spacek
	
					
				Image Credit: Kristina Bumphrey			
			
	LaKeith Stanfield, Robert Pattinson, Lynne Ramsay, Jennifer Lawrence and Sissy Spacek at the â€œDie My Loveâ€ New York premiere at AMC Lincoln Square on Nov. 1 in New York City.

		
			
			
	Jimmy Tatro and Zoey Deutch
	
					
				Image Credit: Variety via Getty Images			
			
	Date night! Jimmy Tatro and Zoey Deutch stun at the 2025 LACMA Art + Film Gala in Los Angeles on Nov. 1.

		
			
			
	Kaia Gerber and Cindy Crawford
	
					
				Image Credit: Variety via Getty Images			
			
	Kaia Gerber and Cindy Crawford make it a family affair at the 2025 LACMA Art + Film Gala.

		
			
			
	Demi Moore, Salma Hayek and Cynthia Erivo
	
					
				Image Credit: Getty Images for LACMA			
			
	Talk about a triple threat. Demi Moore, Salma Hayek and Cynthia Erivo pose at the LACMA Art+Film Gala.

		
	
	


	
		More from Variety
	
	
					

			
			
			
			
	
			
					

			
			
			
			
	
			
					

			
			
			
			
	
			
					

			
			
			
			
	
			
					

			
			
			
			
	
			
					

			
			
			
			
	
			
			
	
			
		

		

	
		More From Our Brands

title: Sexy Stars Turnin' Up the Heat With Spicy Red Hair
description:
Sexy Stars With
                          Spicy Red Hair ...
                          Happy Red
body:
Sexy Stars With
                          Spicy Red Hair ...
                          Happy Red Head Day!
                      
                  
                        Published November 5, 2025 1:15 PM PST
                                                                            
      
    
      
        
              
    
    
          It's National Red Hair Day ... and, we've put together a gallery of stars with bright red locks lookin' spicier than a big bag of Flamin' Hot Cheetos.
      
    
          While only about 4% of Americans are natural redheads, anyone can add a little rosy coloring to their hair ... just look at Megan Fox, who matched her glowing mane to her fierce nails!
      
    
          Karol G put in similar coloring to her own long locks ... while Megan Thee Stallion decided to go with maroon instead of the more vibrant blazing red of these other stars.
      

                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          Katseye's own Lara Raj also got adventurous with her hair choices ... throwing a little bit o' magenta in her hair and a sultry look on her face. Dua Lipa, Brittany Mahomes, Bella Thorne and more stars have hit their local salons to dye their locks, too!
      
    
          Red alert ... it won't be National Red Hair Day for much longer -- so, enjoy our gall before crossing out the day on your calendar with some red ink!
      
      
              
          
                          
                Megan Fox
              
                          
                Hotties & Bodies
              
                          
                Hot Bodies
              
                          
                Holidaze
              
                          
                Photo Galleries

schema.headline: Sexy Stars Turnin' Up the Heat With Spicy Red Hair

                        Published November 5, 2025 12:55 PM PST
                                                                      |
                Updated November 5, 2025 2:06 PM PST
                                    
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          TMZ Sports is going live from the newsroom to discuss the day's biggest stories ... but we don't just want folks to watch and enjoy the conversation, we want y'all to get involved!!
      
    
          Hit the comment section as Babcock, Lucas, Mojo and the whole crew break down the most important topics of the day ... and we'll be interacting with viewers throughout the program between 1 and 2 PM PT.
      
    
          So tune in, make fun of us, share your two cents, sound off about your favorite team ... nothing is out of bounds.
      
    
          Wednesday's show will feature an exclusive interview with Dana White, Taylor Lewan's status for Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce's wedding, Tim Tebow and much more!!

title: Mary Bonnet Feels 'Proud' of Herself After Giving Up Drinking
description:
'Selling Sunset's' Mary Bonnet
                          Life's Way Nicer Without Alcohol!
body:
'Selling Sunset's' Mary Bonnet
                          Life's Way Nicer Without Alcohol!
                      
                  
                        Published November 5, 2025 12:14 PM PST
                                                                      |
                Updated November 5, 2025 1:06 PM PST
                                    
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Mary Bonnet's had lots of success over the course of her career as a real estate agent ... and one of her proudest achievements is being able to give up drinking.
      
    
          The "Selling Sunset" star spoke to Gurus Magazine and said her decision to lay off the sauce was part of a spiritual overhaul on an apparent healing journey.
      
    
          Mary said while she didn't really have a "problem" with alcohol, she started seeing it as an impediment to her health and as a source of anxiety, even though it used to help her relax.
      

          She eventually switched over to mocktails, and said she is "grounded and centered" in a way she hadn't been before leaving booze behind.
      
    
          Mary still has to deal with high-intensity situations ... like reunions with her "Selling Sunset" castmates ... she even walked out of the taping of the show's explosive Season 9 reunion special.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          She said she wasn't a fan of the "energy" in the room while the special was being filmed -- and took off once she'd had enough of the whole thing.
      
    
          Mary said she wanted to keep a strong "backbone" and stay "respectful" during the ordeal ... but hey, everyone's got their limits.

                Mary Bonnet

title: 'Without a Trace' Star Anthony LaPaglia's Wife Files for Divorce
description:
'Without a Trace' Anthony LaPaglia
                          wife files for divorce
body:
'Without a Trace' Anthony LaPaglia
                          wife files for divorce
                      
                  
                        Published November 5, 2025 11:32 AM PST
                                                                            
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          It's back to the drawing board for Anthony LaPaglia, at least when it comes to relationships ... because his wife Alexandra Henkel just pulled the plug on their marriage.
      
    
          The "Without a Trace" star's other half beelined it to court Tuesday and filed for divorce after 7 years of marriage ... according to new legal docs obtained by TMZ.
      
    
          Alexandra lists Sept. 11 as the date of separation and she's going with the boilerplate "irreconcilable differences" as the reason for the split.
      

          The docs say Anthony and Alexandra got hitched way back in April 2018, but they did not have any children together ... so no child support or custody to hash out here.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          On the issue of spousal support, Alexandra is seeking payments from Anthony ... but she wants to terminate the court's ability to award him spousal support.
      
    
          Alexandra also says she wants to keep a Rolex watch, engagement ring and some assorted jewelry ... and she wants the court to determine how to divvy up the proceeds from the Los Angeles house they recently sold.
      
    
          It's the third divorce for Anthony, who starred as Jack Malone in the CBS crime drama "Without a Trace" from 2002 to 2009, among other roles in TV and movies.

schema.headline: 'Without a Trace' Star Anthony LaPaglia's Wife Files for Divorce
